item.title: Juana Amaya
item.description:
November 12, 1949 - September 5, 2022
Saturday, September 10, 2022

Viewing/Service
2:30pm-4:30pm

Serenity Funeral Home
1140 Almond Tree Lane #306
Las Vegas, NV 89104

It is with great sadness in our hearts that we say goodbye to one of the greatest persons we've ever known. Juana Amaya, 73, passed away on September 5th 2022, after courageously fighting lung cancer for 10 months. Her funeral service will be held on September 10th 2022.

 

Being one of 13 children, Juanita was born on Nov 12, 1949 in Juacaran, El Salvador to Santos Amaya and Leocadia Ramirez. After the passing of her mother at a young age she took on to care for her younger sisters. This experience allowed her to land a career as a nursemaid for many years, with a respected family that would eventually become dear friends. As a nursemaid Juanita was able to travel and live in many countries including The USA, Costa Rica, Panama, Venezuela. She was so full of curiosity and adventure, she immersed herself completely in the culture of each country she visited and immediately was welcomed by the locals. After many years she returned to her home country where she gave birth to her first daughter, followed by her second child 9 years later.

 

As times became tough in El Salvador she looked for other ways to provide for her family. With solid goals in mind and a heart full of hope for a brighter future for her and her children, in 1987 she crossed the border to the USA. Leaving her two children behind in the care of family and friends was a sacrifice she had to make to achieve her goals. With her knowledge of other cultures she immediately adapted, made friends, and found a job. She worked hard and long hours focused on providing for her children and helping the family she left back home. During the following years she had a third child and with all her sacrifice by 1993, the family was made whole again in New York City, where they live happily together striving to be the best they can be.

 

 With a passion for caring for people, Juanita made friends anywhere she went. She loved to talk and laugh. Communication came easy to her, whether it was the guy at the corner of 164th and Jamaica asking for a quarter at 5am or the CEO of the Dry Cleaner she worked for. She was a beam of life that people gravitated towards. Not only because she was always her honest, caring and loyal self who would give the shirt off her back if she could, but also her contagious laugh that would light a house with laughter and bring joy to those around her. With her children by her side she continued to work hard to provide the best of the best for her children while still financially helping family back home, and assisting many other family and friends take the journey to the USA.

 

In 2014, Juanita received one of the greatest news ever. She was to become a grandmother. Without a second thought she packed her bags and moved to Las Vegas to check off another goal, build a life around her greatest joys, grandchildren. She cared and loved her two grandkids, Logan and Austin or as she would called them, mi Gatito and mi Ratoncito. She grew up surrounded by loved ones, at a young age she learned to love and care for others and even in her last days she was making sure that everyone was cared for. Her generosity, loyalty, honesty, her care and love will live on through those lives she touched and those loved ones she leaves behind.

 

Juana Amaya is survived by her oldest Sandra Duran, her son Eli Martinez, and youngest Karen Sypraseouth along with her two grandchildren Logan and Austin Sypraseouth

]]>

Willie Mae accepted the Lord as her savior at a young age when she attended Mt. Carmel M.B, church, later in life as an adult she joined the Greater Salem M.B. Church (Rev. L. Jenkins) and was re-baptized. Serving her time there she felt time to move on.

Joining the Evening Star M.B. Church where she served on the Mother Board under the leadership of Bishop V.L. Dixon for 12 years. After relocating to Las Vegas, feeling a void of missing her church family she was introduced to the Tabernacle of Praise Church (Pastor M. E. Jackson) where she has been a faithful member of the Mother Board & TOP church Family.

Willie Mae and her family relocated to Chicago, IL from Alabama as children. Although she had her primary Education to begin in Birmingham, she continued her education attending and graduating High School (Englewood High).

She worked for Montgomery Wards retail for 15 years and started with Golden Manor Nursing Home for many years until her health forced her to retire from the workforce.

Married her high school love, Jimmie White (precedes in death) to this union they had three sons James, Anthony (Both precedes her in death) & Michael. She had 8 grandkids, 5 great grand kids, and a special God given daughter Demita (Kevin).

She leaves to cherish her memories, her big family and friends, a host of cousins, nieces, grand nieces, nephews', grand nephews and her entire extended church family and all who loved her.
]]>

item.title: Gregory Lewis
item.description:
August 16, 1952 - July 29, 2022
My Way

And now the end is here
And sol face that final curtain
My friend I'll make it clear
I'll state my case, of which I'm certain
I've lived a life that's full
I traveled each and every highway
And more, much more
I did it, I did it my way
Regrets, I've had a few
But then again too few to mention
I did what I had to do
1 saw it through without exemption
1 planned each charted course
Each careful step along the byway
And more, much, much more
I did it, I did it my way
Yes, there were times I'm sure you knew
When 1 bit off more than I could chew
But through it all, when there was doubt
late it up and spit it out
1 faced it all and I stood tall and did it my way
For what is a man, what has he got?
If not himself then he has naught
Not to say the things that he truly feels
And not the words of someone who kneels
Let the record shows I took all the blows and did it my way

Psalm 30 

I will extol You, O Lord, for You have lifted me up, And have
not let my enemies rejoice over me. O Lord my God, I cried
to You for help, and You healed me. O Lord, You have
brought up my soul from Sheol; You have kept me alive,
that I would not go down to the pit. Sing praise to the Lord,
you His godly ones, And give thanks to His holy name. For
His anger is but for a moment, His favor is for a lifetime;
Weeping may last for the night, But a shout of joy comes in
the morning. Now as for me, I said in my prosperity, " will
never be moved." O Lord, by Your favor You have made my
mountain to stand strong; You hid Your face, I was
dismayed. To You, O Lord, I called, And to the Lord I made
supplication: "What profit is there in my blood, if I go down
to the pit? Will the dust praise You? Will it declare Your
faithfulness? "Hear, O Lord, and be gracious to me; O Lord,
be my helper." You have turned for me my mourning into
dancing; You have loosed my sackcloth and girded me with
gladness, That my soul may sing praise to You and not be
silent. O Lord my God, I will give thanks to You forever.

item.title: Eddie Harris
item.description:
November 7, 1933 - May 14, 2022
Eddie Harris was born on November 7, 1933 in Beulah MS, to the parents of Walter Harris and Willie Mae
Hollis. Eddie was the third child of nine children, Eddie's siblings are Ruby Weston, Walter Harris Jr, Willa
Mae Smother, Melvin Harris, Rosa Lee Thompson and Cletonia Dickens, In 1940 Eddie's family moved to
Chicago IL, and there is where he would start his first job as a paper boy at the age of seven in the efforts to
help support his family. Eddie graduated from Wendal Phillips High School in 1952 and enlisted in the
United States Army in 1953, Eddie served 4 years.

In 1956, Eddie met his forever love Ethel Bessie Rockwell, when he walked her home at the request of his
friend James Gardner after a skate night outing. Eddie and Ethel's friendship tumed into a life long union and
they married on August 12, 1957, They conceived five children, Eddie Harris Jr, Donna Marie Harris,
Timothy Harris, Edward Lloyd Harris and Darryl Maurice Harris now Israel Ben Ezra Kohen Nissim, Eddie
Jr, and Timothy proceeded them in death shortly after childbirth. Eddie worked as a Foreman for Sherwin
Williams Paint from 1959 up until 1964 when he started his own business as a newspaper distributor in the
city of Chicago; The Drexel News Agency.

 Eddie lived a full and prosperous life with his wife, children and
grandchildren until July 11, 2013 when his wife Ethel passed away. Eddie Moved to Las Vegas and spent the
last nine years of his life to the fullest of his life with his family. Eddie enjoyed bowling with his entire family,
attending celebrations and holiday functions, family vacations to California and Arizona. He had a diverse
" taste for music and dancing and a forever a Cubbie and Bears fan. (He did go to the occasional White Sox
game with his sons, without compliant), Dad, was a honest, loving, hard working man that taught his sons
and daughter, well by being there, to show them how to love. Eddie leaves to mourn his three children, Donna
Harris, Edward Harris, Israel Nissim, grandchildren, Tanisha Harris, Ethel and Dionna Simpson, Vicky and
Author Moore, Deborah, Obediah, Karom Harris, Vasthi Brawdy and Reginald House and a host of
grandchildren, family and friends.
]]>

item.title: Vera Lee Johnson
item.description:
May 17, 1958 - May 7, 2022
Vera Lee Berry Johnson was born on May 17, 1958, to Leon Berry and
Vivian Anderson in Natchez, Mississippi and is the middle child to 8
children. The family migrated to Monrovia, CA when she was only 6
months old. She completed her formal education and graduated from
Mount Olive Continuation in Monrovia, Ca in 1976.

In 1978 Vera bared her first child and had another daughter in 1981.
Vera relocated to Detroit, MI in 1983 with the father of her children
(Reuben) and later moved back to California in 1990 engaged to Jeffrey.
In 1992 Vera attended Citrus College in Glendora, CA and earned her license as a
cosmetologist. She also learned how to play her favorite card game at school
(Spades). In 1998 Vera moved to San Bernardino with her grandson Eric in tow
where she met her best friend and love of her life "Leslie "Bookie" Johnson in 1991.

Vera relocated to Las Vegas with Bookie in 2000 with her grandson Eric in Tow.
Life happened, Vera married someone, but said that marriage didn't count. She
married Bookie upon his return in June 2006. Yes….. Vera was a rolling stone, just
kidding, she just didn't take any crap from anyone and when she was done, she was
done, she's a Taurus and I guess it's the Bull in her. Vera grew up in a house of music
and she loved music, her favorite rapper in this era was Cardi B and her lifetime
love was Smokey Robinson. Even though she loved her some Bookie, he had to
make room for Smokey. She called herself "Sexy VB." Vera spent her days spoiling
her grandkids and worked as a security guard in Vegas up until she became
disabled. She always had a revolving door for nearly anyone who needed her help.
Her heart was as big as her mouth and everybody loved her to a fault, even when
she was as mean as a grizzly and as stubborn as a bull, you couldn't tell her nothing
because she was sexy, funny, and looked better than her kids, let her tell it.

Vera preceded in death by her husband Leslie "Bookie" Johnson, stepson Jamari
Johnson, parents Vivian and Leon Berry, siblings Vivian Berry Jr. and LT, mother-
in-law Ruby Johnson, cousin in law Darryl Riley, aunts Yvonne Clark, Elizabeth
Ward, and her close friend Wanda Stevenson. Vera leaves to cherish her
memories, siblings Leona & Charity Berry, Yvonne Baber, Russell & Leon Berry.
Daughters: Katrina Allen & husband Tommy Allen, & Ruby Butler. Children gained
through marriage; Cher Williams, Jazurie and Jeremy and her daughters half
siblings; Sequina & Reuben Butler Jr. Grandkids: Eric Williams, Drew 'Anthoni
Alejos, Charles Tate III and RayNieceya "her princess" Stevenson and a
greatgrandchild on the way (Charles Tate & Ariel Laney), Father in-law Tommy
Johnson, Sister In-laws Melissa and Tina and a host of friends, nieces, nephews,
and cousins that loved her dearly especially her Amber Wamber, Shawnie Pooh
and a very special friend Audrey McCullum.
]]>

Neal Bernard Lindsey Sr. was born to Ethel Olivia Meeks and Henry Lindsey in Bovina, Mississippi on February 28, 1944. Neal was raised by John Archie Jackson respectfully acknowledging him as his father. Neal left Mississippi in the early 60's traveling to California starting his own family, managing realty property, and beginning an apparel business. Later he traveled to Las Vegas joining other family and friends. Neal completed his education in 1989 with the State of NV. Dept. of Education. While managing his own shoeshine business he captured many hearts with his outstretched hand and catchy phrases making his name, "Magnificent Neal”, true to those who knew him well. Neal found God and was baptized in 2001 at Unity Baptist Church and later became an attendee of Evergreen Baptist Church in Las Vegas. Neal leaves to cherish his memories his children: Neal Bernard Lindsey Jr.; Carlos; Kalab; Lolita Lindsey and Gwyneth Chaneal Olive Lindsey. 7 sisters: Christine; Linda; Peaches; Loraine; Armonica; Faye; Tina. 3 brothers: Donald; Stanley and Oliver along with a host of many relatives and close friends. Proceeding Neal in death: Ethal Meeks, John Jackson, Curtis Lindsey, Earl Lindsey, Queen E. Lindsey, Glen L. Jackson, Terry Jackson, and Jurlene Jackson. The family would like to thank everyone for their prayers, love, and acts of kindness during this time. Please continue to keep us in prayer and lifted before the Lord. Thank you.

Florence Cato was born 15 minutes after her brother, Lawrence James Cato, on January 13, 1938
to William and Lucille Grant Cato in Muskogee, Oklahoma.

 Mom accepted Christ at an early age. Only six years old when her mother
died, she relocated to Stockton, California to live with her
Aunt. Florence attended Edison High School and graduated in
1955. She later moved to Los Angeles, California where she
worked for Pacific Telephone Co, now known as AT&T
Florence retired after 30 years and moved to Las Vegas, Nevada.
She then worked as a slot attendant and retired at the age of 82.

Florence was soft-spoken, loving, and always
working to support her family. She had a heart of gold and was
dearly loved by her entire family. MOM WILL TRULY BE MISSED.
 
She was preceded in death by her father and mother William
and Lucille Grant Cato; four brothers, Wesley Cato, William
Cato, Booker T. Cato and Davidson Cato; one sister, Mercedes
Cato Waller; son, Tyron Jones; daughter, Tiffany Delane
Dixon-Briggs; stepson Marvin Potts; great grandson Divine
Humphrey, and great, great granddaughter Laniah Rankin.

She leaves to cherish her memory her twin brother, Lawrence
James Cato; two sisters, Marie Cato-Heath and Irene Cato-
Antwine; a daughter, Joyce Reneé Jones; two sons, James
Anthony "Jimmy" Jones, Sr. and Marco Edwin Potts; three
stepsons, Mahlon Potts, Jr., Terry Briggs and Sandy June Briggs; four
stepdaughters, Linda Carolyn "Katie" Allen, Sandra, and Wanda
granddaughters, 31 Briggs; nine grandsons, nine
great grandchildren; two great, great
grandchildren; nieces, nephews and friends too numerous to
mention, but you know who you are. With LOVE.

item.description:

Teresa Ann Maddox was born February 6th,1968; To parents Joe & Marjorie Maddox. She Was
born in Las Vegas, NV and spent many childhood years in Epps, Louisiana. She was the
youngest of four siblings; Cedric Maddox Sr, Debra Joseph, and twin Ike Maddox.

As a young child Teresa attended Pilgrim Rest Missionary Church where she sung in the choir.
She grew up in legendary Vegas neighborhoods such as Maddison Terrace and Windsor
"Winslow" Park. She attended Western High School and her career of choice was hospitality.

Teresa was loved by many and deemed " The life of the Party" or as she would call it the
"Hostess with the mostest". Her hobbies were cooking her signature dishes; T baby tacos with
all the trimmings and fixings, crab boils and what we called growing up shut up and eat
meals. Lounging while watching the lifetime and the animal channel learning facts favorite
wild cats, alligators, and birds. Playing the penny machines at her favorite spots.
She had a very vibrant personality which drew people to her natural and very blunt and direct
sense of humor. In her last days she spent time with her favorite niece Connie, and spreading love.

Teresa leaves her legacy in the hands of her three children Shakema McCraney of Las Vegas
Marcus Maddox Sr of Las Vegas, and Shareese Stephens of Pagosa Colorado. She is
proceeded in death by her parents Joe and Marjorie Maddox, brother Cedric Maddox Sr, and
grand daughters Aniyah Allen and Nevaeh Maddox , 7 grandchildren, brother and sister; Ike
Maddox and Debra Joseph, A host of nieces and nephews, friends & family,

]]>

Dear Ones - Early on Sat. April 2nd our sweet father of 91yrs. passed peacefully in Las Vegas @ home after suffering from a stroke several days prior. He was very tired & becoming quit weak, he had been surrounded by his family who loved him. Our Dad was born in Connecticut, in his young adult life he joined the Marines & became a Corporal. He married our Mom & had 2 girls, later divorced & married Catalina who was his faithful wife of over 40 yrs. He was an amazing salesmen. Loved the Dessert especially Gold Point. He is survived by daughters, Sherry, Carla, 3 granddaughters & 1 grandson, 4 great granddaughters & 1 great grandson. We will truly miss his wit, his tender ways & of course his presence, but he is with his maker now. Bless his beautiful heart & rest now w/the angels.

item.title: Dolores Lucy Leserra
item.description:
April 21, 1938 - March 25, 2022
Viewing
3:00pm-4:00pm
Wednesday March 30, 2022

Service 
4:00pm-6:00pm
Wednesday March 30, 2022

Serenity Funeral Home
1140 Almond Tree Lane #306
Las Vegas, Nevada 89104
Dolores Lucy Leserra was born on April 21, 1938 in
White Plains, New York to Frank and Jean Anunziato.
She lived with her parents and siblings, Jeanette,
Jean, Anthony, Diane, and Thomas. As a young lady,
she enjoyed going out and socializing with her friends

When Dee was 17, she met and fell in love with Michael
Leserra. They were married in 1956. Together they had
Frank, Donna, Michael, and Dawn. They raised their
kids in Margate, Florida, where Dee managed various
restaurants. Shortly after Dee and Mike divorced in
1980, she met Dexter Boice. In 1981, they were
married. Together with Dawn, they moved to Houston,
Texas. She ran the Denny's in Galveston. Dee always
enjoyed her annual girls' trip to Las Vegas, NV

Enamored with the bright lights of Vegas, they moved
there in 1985. In Vegas she continued working for
Denny's and later The Pink Pony. Even after losing her
husband, Dexter, she continued to work and enjoyed
the Joker Poker at the El Cortez. She had many
devoted regular customers until she retired from
waitressing. She developed a love for cruises and
traveling with her friends and family.

Throughout Dee's life, she was a selfless mother to her
four children, and Mema to her ten grandchildren and
18 great grandchildren. She was devoted and giving to
all. She was known to have a house open to everyone
and loved her kids and their kids fiercely. Dee would
give the shirt off her back to any in need. She was a
wonderful cook and loving host. She would always
make sure that you left her house feeling full and
loved. Dee's house was filled with those who loved her,
and were loved dearly by her until she passed on
March 25. 2022.
]]>

item.title: Randy Marquis Proby Jr.
item.description:
April 11, 1981 - March 25, 2022
Randy Marquis Proby Jr. was born in Chicago, IL April 11, 1981, to the union of
Randy Proby Sr. and Tanya Proby. He spent most of his life in Las Vegas, NV. Randy
graduated from Cheyenne High School in 1999..00h Prince had a perfect song for that.

Randy was a Shipping and Receiving Manager at Turnberry where he worked
for 18 years. Randy was a man who loved his family and friends so very much. He
was truly the life of EVERY party and family gathering. Randy was a Lego loving,
Magic and video game playing, good mac & cheese making, movie watching,
comic book reading, second-degree black belt karaoke singing man. No one had a
greater sense of style! His jerseys, anime shirts, "ugly" Christmas sweaters, award
winning Halloween costumes, and we can't forget his amazing kilts!

Randy was preceded in death by both of his Grandmothers: Rosie L. Knight and
Flossie L. Perry, Grandfather Gerome Beatty, and Aunt Sharon Beatty.
Randy is survived by his Father Randy Proby Sr, Mother Tanya Proby, Grandfather
John H. Perry Jr., Sisters Briana Proby, Randi Proby, Arial Proby, Samantha
Donaldson and Mynesha Donaldson, Brothers Jarvas Donaldson and Michael Finks
and a host of aunts, uncles, nieces, nephews, and cousins

In Randy's Facebook words when he quit Magic...well one of the times he quit again
"Its been fun and I shall see you all around.…keep slinging those spells Summoners in
my absence, to the blind eternities I go, Peace.

To know him was to love him. Despite it all, he lived life and had fun! Randy Jr, Little
Randy, The Boy, Snap, Mono-Randy, Randy Baby Yeah, Sexual Chocolate McLovin
we will miss you!
]]>

Luther Ray Bailey was born in Fort Worth, Texas on October 21st, 1948, to
parents, Luther and Hattie Bailey. He was well known by the name Ray.
Ray came to Las Vegas in 1954 with his family. He attended Westside
School, Matt Kelly Elementary and graduated from Clark High School.

His love for cars inspired him to become a mechanic. Later he moved to
Southern California, and took a job as a welder. Ray served in the United
States Marines and was honorably discharged.

Ray loved to fish and hunt. He was very comical and loved to be with his
brothers. Ray loved his parents and cared for them before he moved to
Tyler, Texas in 2021.

Ray leaves to mourn and cherish his memories, his father and mother,
Elder Luther and Mother Hattie Bailey; 4 sons, Ray Ray, Maurice, Cornell
and Deon Butler; 6 brothers, Jimmy, Charles, Roy, Marcus, Brian and
Kevin; 4 sisters, Emma (Tom) Mikkelson, Christine Slusher, Patricia Green,
and Gwendolyn Grant; 3 daughters, Dina Bailey, Felicia Butler, and
Karmisha Bailey; a host of grandchildren, great-grandchildren, family and
friends.

Gertrude Delourise Thomas was born on July 4, 1941 in Tallulah, Louisiana
to Burl Lee and Blanche Dotson, her parents who
both preceded her in death. She was the second oldest of
fourteen children who affectionally seen her as their second mom.

Gertrude attended Reuben McCall Sr. High School in 1960. In
1961 she began her life long residency where she would meet
her future husband Julius Thomas Jr. who she was married to
for 46 years and who also preceded her in death.

She had an extensive career at the Sahara Hotel and Casino
from which she retired from in 2012. Some of her hobbies
included the love of sports. She was an exceptional basketball
player in high school. Her most happiest times were when she
attended her children and grandchildren games and events.
Gertrude was also an extraordinary cook and seamstress.

Gertrude was called home to be with her Heavenly Father and
she leaves to cherish her memories, her loving children; Glenda
and Leon Austin, Brenda K. Lee, Carolyn and Stephen Franklin,
Debra Thomas, Latanya Thomas, Fred and Cy Williams,
Howard Bradford, god-children; Sherrie and Anthony Burton, 12
grandchildren, 11 great-grandchildren, a host of cousins, nieces and nephews.

She was preceded in death by siblings; Barbara Lee,
Ernastine Toliver Jackson, George Banks and Hershey
Dotson and Great Granddaughter Kaylee Jamette Davis. She
was survived by siblings; Elnora Lee, Gloria and Roosevelt
Williams, Lily Gains, Eugene and Essie Lee, Irma Lee, Blanche
and Gerald McNeil, Pearl Wiggins, Earl Wiggins, Joe and
Jennifer Dotson, Margie Dotson, Deloris Dotson, and Thelma Dotson.
